Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Digital Inequalities in the Heartland: Exploring the Information Security Experiences of Marginalized Internet Users

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to understand how Internet technology may affect patrons' privacy and data security when they use public access computers, and to develop technical solutions that will enable these individuals to go online more safely and securely. The project concentrates especially on people who are economically poor and vulnerable to risk, such as very young or old people, people of color, immigrants, Native people, non-English speakers, and the disabled. Often these patrons must rely on public libraries for their broadband Internet access. The research team will study the day-to-day use patterns and security experiences of users in the public libraries of two diverse communities in northeast Kansas, and develop a prototype device with built-in security and privacy protections that can be delivered using an inexpensive, portable USB-style device to help patrons go online more safely. The researchers' goal is to enable these public-use patrons to have the same access and protections as those using their own computers.

Anecdotal evidence suggests that public-use Internet users may be more likely the targets of online scams, identity theft, differential and predatory pricing, and discriminatory profiling; the direct impact of these security risks on life chances can be profound. To understand the security experiences of these marginalized users, the research team will conduct ethnographic research in the public libraries of two diverse communities in northeast Kansas. Whereas this field research will help us develop detailed knowledge of the subjects' activities and needs and to modify our technical strategy, we will develop, as a starting point, a prototype with three functions: 1) password and key protection; 2) browsing privacy and portability; and 3) fine-grained, ubiquitous control delivered with a USB-style device. This novel and, as of now, untested, interdisciplinary approach seeks to address fundamental knowledge shortcomings and practical challenges in the areas of security, privacy, and trust.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite the critical importance of Internet access for social and economic inclusion, many in the US remain digitally disenfranchised because they do not own their own computers and/or have broadband Internet access at a personal residence. These individuals turn to public libraries for their computing needs and these settings profoundly shape their digital experiences. Because these users computing lives are resource-limited, transient, and less private and secure than those who own their computers, we see them as experiencing digital homelessness.

Our work has advanced the scientific understanding of public computing and the digital experiences of historically marginalized communities and has contributed to the Social and Behavior Sciences literatures on data profiling, digital inequalities, and social privacy as well as scholarly work in Computer and Information Science & Engineering in computers and human behavior, trust in computing environments, and internet security. Moreover, we have prototyped a digital home to address the problem of digital homelessness. 

Our research outcomes are based on two major activities:

1) From September 2017 to June 2018 we conducted systematic participant observation and field interviews at several libraries in the Midwest. Rsearchers volunteered as Computer Techs at Help Desks and spent fifteen hours per week for more than 700 hours total hours in the field. This proximity allowed researchers to interact with and observe the patrons and staffs and their computing. Some patrons and staff were invited to participate in field interviews were they were asked questions about their use of the Internet and their online privacy and security experiences. The researchers conducted 40 field interviews (33 patron, 7 staff). Both interviews transcripts and fieldnotes were analyzed using the qualitative data analysis program, Atlas.TI.

2)  We have utilized our initial findings to produce a novel prototype device, we have named the Personal User Privacy and Security (PUPS) appliance (see image). The PUPS appliance utilizes inexpensive and easily replaceable hardware (a USB-3 flash drive) and our own modified open source code to automate a virtualized Windows desktop for use on public computers. Potential users would be able to carry their low-cost, encrypted PUPS appliance with them to the library, plug it in to any library computer, log in, and use the computer as though it were their home PC. Smart state-saving allows users to save items to their desktop, make and utilize their own folder system, even end a session with a Microsoft Word document open and restore that session at a later time on a different computer with the same document open. These intuitive shifts address some of the difficulties of learning secure or ease-of-use behaviors on public computers, where one must have a more in-depth plan for file management which tends to result in confusion and data loss for public computer users.  Further, this device is equipped with security features that address many of the insecure browsing habits of this population and advertises such features as a method of assuaging the sometimes-unfounded security fears that inhibit effective computer use for those individuals. By pre-loading a suite of security features and preserving a stable folder system for imitating home computer settings on public computer machines, this device helps to mitigate the many diverse use-issues that arise from primarily public access computer use.
